article.description: Chris Webber scored 24 points and made a 21-footer with 1.5 seconds remaining Sunday night as the Sacramento Kings remained unbeaten at home this season with a 101-99 victory over the Orlando Magic.
article.headline: McGrady's 36 points not enough against Kings

images.name: Webber_Chris 021117 inline
images.caption: Chris Webber shoots the game-winning shot in the final seconds to beat the visiting Magic.

article.linkText: Webber keeps Kings perfect at home with buzzer-beater
article.story:
SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) -- Chris Webber saved the Sacramento Kings from a potentially embarrassing loss. The All-Star forward scored 24 points and made a 21-footer with 1.5 seconds remaining as the Kings stayed unbeaten at home this season with a 101-99 victory Sunday night over the Orlando Magic. Tracy McGrady made two 3-pointers, and Pat Burke tipped in a shot with four seconds left as Orlando rallied from an eight-point deficit in the final minute to tie the game at 99-99. Following a timeout, Webber took the inbounds pass, and Bobby Jackson went around him to give Webber some room. He quickly put up a shot over Shawn Kemp that went straight in. Darrell Armstrong's desperation shot from near midcourt was not close at the buzzer. In was only the second game-winning basket in Webber's five seasons with the Kings, who are 5-0 at home. "I just felt real confident about it before I shot it,'' said Webber, who had 10 rebounds. "There was a moment of suspense, you're holding your breath until it goes in. I don't care if you've done this a thousand times, it feels good when it happens.'' Jackson, who made 10 of 11 shots and had 22 points, said the play was not designed for Webber. "He was wide open, they (the defenders) followed me,'' Jackson said. "I thought I was going to get the ball.'' The Kings led 98-90 with 41 seconds left. A steal by Darrell Armstrong on an inbounds pass followed by Burke's tip in nearly sent the game into overtime. "We've got to get better than that late in the game,'' Jackson said. "We darn near lost it. I would have cried if we lost that game.'' McGrady, the NBA's leading scorer, finished with 36 points, 14 rebounds and seven assists for Orlando. The Magic lost their second straight game and eighth overall at Arco Arena, where they haven't won since Dec. 19, 1993. Bothered by Doug Christie's defense, McGrady made just 13 of 33 shots. He scored 41 points in a 125-121 home victory earlier this month against the Kings. "Doug is obviously a great defender,'' McGrady said. "All the points I got I had to work for because he's a veteran and he knows all the tricks.'' Peja Stojakovic scored 17 points, and Christie had 11 for the Kings. Vlade Divac added eight points and 10 rebounds. Armstrong scored 20 points for the Magic, who were coming off a 135-92 loss Saturday to Golden State -- the worst defeat in franchise history. Shawn Kemp had 10 points and 13 rebounds. Burke added 12 points. Orlando was missing Grant Hill, who dressed for the game but rested his sore left ankle. Hill, who played just 18 games the last two seasons, missed his first game this season. "I asked him about it before we went out to warm up and he said it was sore, so I pulled him,'' Orlando coach Doc Rivers said. "It's a day to day thing, but it's better than losing him for the whole season.'' Although the Kings began the third quarter with a 13-2 run, Orlando still managed to close the period with a 71-70 lead. Burke scored seven points, and McGrady made a 3-pointer with 20 seconds left to put the Magic ahead.

Game notes
Despite shooting 33 percent in the first half, Orlando led 46-41. ... Orlando outrebounded the Kings 53-38, including 22-5 on the offensive boards. ... Sacramento has sold out the last 137 games, the longest streak in the NBA. ... The Kings had five free throws through three quarters and finished 14 of 18.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
